because we don't want to

2908.92.text:
and we want a gracious

2916.04.text:
It's also on my

2918.51.text:
But three ways to end

2922.17.text:
First way, when you've

2924.85.text:
with someone, oh, it's
so nice to talk to you

2927.86.text:
about the 49ers and

2931.64.text:

2936.80.text:

2940.04.text:
but it was so nice to

2941.83.text:
And then I summarized
a little phrase

2944.67.text:
so he knows I was
listening and that I

2948.95.text: So nice to talk to you about.

2952.07.text:
And then what you
do is, if you want

2954.21.text:
their card-- do we
still give out cards?

2958.25.text:
I had one guy on a plane said to
me, oh, I take people's cards,

2961.29.text:
take a picture,
and throw them out.

2963.11.text: Well, that makes me feel good.

2965.56.text: You could have not told me that.

2969.79.text:
And what if you
want someone's card?

2971.29.text: Oh, do you have a card?

2973.43.text:
Now, I once asked that to a
gentleman who looked at me--

2975.81.text:
I tell you-- totally
deadpan and said, yes.

2985.38.text:
About 20 years later,

2987.27.text:
Why did you just say yes

2989.97.text:
Here was his answer--
you hadn't asked for one.

3001.36.text:
And then what if they
don't ask for yours?

3003.74.text:
What you could say-- and this is
completely contrarian to those

3007.74.text:
who want to get to the

3010.82.text:
Say, may I offer
you one of mine?

3013.26.text:
May I please offer
you one of mine?

3015.23.text:
Well, why don't I
just give them a card?

3017.09.text:
Because there's something about
the manners and the etiquette

3020.55.text:
and showing that
you have manners

3026.11.text: OK, then here's what I would do.

3028.43.text:
I would then walk a quarter of
the room away to someone else.

3034.66.text:
No, to someone else
who is standing alone,

3039.21.text:
because I know he doesn't
want to be standing alone,

3041.38.text: or to another group of people.

3043.22.text:
But walking a quarter
of the room away

3046.07.text:
is really important, because
that way you don't make someone

3048.57.text:
feel you've just turned
your back on them.

3051.54.text:
That's where that
expression comes from.

3054.55.text:
Another way that you
exit-- and by the way,

3059.34.text:
Then you can follow up later

I know that sounds antiquated,

3070.20.text:
Sometimes if you

3071.70.text:
that you really want to

3079.52.text:
You can take out your

3088.40.text:
That will really show

And by the way, those of you

3095.64.text:
in the book-- and

3097.06.text:
where-- there is a

3101.09.text:
But if you run your phone

3104.14.text:

3111.02.text:
chapter that has to

3113.48.text:
And I wish I could

3119.74.text: Oh, there's one on the back.

3121.92.text:
But the one inside leads to

3125.48.text:
Thank you, he pointed out

3127.56.text:
I tried to make this book

3131.32.text:
So on the back,

3133.17.text:
And when you run your

3135.54.text:
is up pops a video

3137.50.text: different and new in the book.

3138.95.text:
So did that help

3141.67.text:
Let's just say-- let me

3143.72.text:
Let's say you had a

3149.12.text:
Don't say, I've had a

3151.12.text:
because it hasn't

3152.64.text:
It's been like pulling

3155.04.text:
So what you say to them is-- and
don't any of you say this to me

3158.95.text:
later-- I hope you enjoy

3165.90.text:
And you still walk a
quarter of the room

3167.60.text:
away, because that person might
be thinking about something

3170.23.text:
else that happened at home,
and they're not responsive

3176.30.text:
But the next time you see

3179.56.text:
And then the third
one isn't really

3183.57.text: The third one is, oh, I see Joe.

3187.31.text: Why don't you come on over?

3190.40.text:
And then you're in a
group conversation.

3192.61.text: So you have three ways to exit.

3194.30.text:
Well, one question
I'm often asked

3196.11.text:
is, what do I do
if I forgot a name?

3198.19.text:
Have any of you
encountered that?

3204.03.text:
I know that there are name
and memory specialists that

3207.04.text:
will tell you, much
like Doctor Seuss,

3210.07.text:
to put a cat in a vat
in a hat on their head.

3214.23.text:
But what I would say is, when
you forgot someone's name

3216.66.text:
and you know their face is
familiar, save some time

3220.62.text:
and go over and say, it's
just been one of those days.

3227.27.text:
Could you help me out and
remind me of your name?

3234.76.text:
Every person has
forgotten someone's name.

3237.94.text:
If it's your sister or your
mother-in-law, not so cool.

3241.78.text:
But people have
forgotten people's names.

3244.23.text:
And then they'll tell you
stories how they forgot a name.

3246.84.text:
But if you say that
up front, that works.

3250.89.text:
And I learned this
from a gentleman

3252.35.text:
who was the vice president
of the Harlem Globetrotters.

3255.27.text:
Well, I knew he was the vice
president in the main office

3260.67.text:
He said-- and I kept this in
the book 25 years-- he said,

3263.74.text:
Susan, what you tell people
is when they go somewhere

3267.08.text:
and they see someone that
they recognize but they really

3270.58.text:
don't remember a name,
he said, always-- even

3273.54.text:
if you've seen that
person five times--

3276.33.text:
always put your hand
out and say your name.

3282.44.text:
He's just looking at me
smiling, going, oh my God.

3288.89.text:
When you go over
and say your name,

3291.90.text:
you can bet if you didn't
remember their name after six

3294.93.text:
months, they have no
clue of your name either.

3297.69.text:
But when you see your
name, 90% of the time,

3302.29.text:
Then you both know
each other and reminded

3305.63.text:
And then you're
having a conversation.

3308.16.text:
Does that help you
around remembering names?

3312.74.text: And then just tell the truth.

I'm going to have

3316.66.text: and then I'm going to close.

CLIFF: I think we're set

3329.17.text:
I've had people say-- and
I'm going to stay here

3331.18.text: so that I sign the book.

I once was signing a book,

3336.15.text:
And the guy looked at

3337.86.text:
You write a whole

3340.44.text:
Because I don't

3341.86.text:
And I said, really,
the autograph was easy.

3345.35.text:
Writing the book, really
hard, but well worth it.

3349.20.text:
Because I know it's served
people over a number of years

3353.57.text:
and continues to serve
people, because I want you all

3356.87.text:
to be able to walk into any

3361.03.text: and meet who you want to meet.

3362.35.text:
And by the way, when you're

3364.77.text:
I saw the Google girl power and
I've seen some Google shirts--

3371.27.text:
I have a shirt that
says, "Give me chocolate,

3379.47.text:
I'm good to end with something
that actually happened.

3383.20.text:
When "How to Work a
Room" first came out,

3384.96.text:
I spoke for the
Commonwealth Club.

3387.40.text:
It was absolutely an honor
for me, a former teacher.

3393.51.text: Two men were in the second row.

3396.17.text: But I went before the talk.

3397.54.text:
I held the book, my
baby, under my arm

3399.75.text: and I-- what brought you here?

3402.42.text:
It was so nice to see
you, thank you for coming.

3405.05.text:
And then one of them looked at
me with the face, and he says,

3407.59.text:
I just have a
question to ask you.

3411.39.text:
I knew it wasn't going
to be a good one.

3413.40.text:
He said, how did you
take a 200 page book

3419.14.text:
and think you're going
to give a 45 minute talk?

3426.54.text:
and I wrote about in the
book-- that I channeled

3429.17.text:
my grandfather, who was known as
having a great sense of humor.

3432.75.text:
And I was so lucky the
answer came to me then

3435.49.text:
that might have happened an
hour later while I hit my head.

3439.11.text: And I looked at the guy.

3440.35.text:
And I said, the only way you
can handle someone that's

3442.60.text:
sounding so negative
is with humor.

3444.76.text:
And I said to him, you
think that was tough?

3447.71.text:
I took a 45 minute talk and
turned it into a 200 page book.

3452.92.text:
And now you have the
300 page version.

3458.03.text:
And I am so delighted
to be here at Google.

3463.43.text:
We now have a whole
new room of-- I've

3468.88.text:
Any questions that come up
that I haven't answered,

3471.91.text: feel free to let me know.

3474.90.text: And I promise you an answer.

3477.80.text:
So thank you very much, and
I hope you'll tell every one.

3482.44.text:
And I'm available, and I'll
keep on Googling, you guys.
